conversation.message: Hello School_C. I’m Student_C. You’re one of my top choices, and I’m very interested in what your program emphasizes (academics, clubs, student support). What qualities are you prioritizing most in applicants this year? [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_C is my 2nd choice, so I should engage seriously. However, School_C’s priority ranks Student_B above me, and Student_B also ranks School_C as their 3rd choice; they may apply if they miss School_A/School_B. Since this is only round 1 and I’m not currently facing my top choice School_B, I should build interest and gather signals without committing immediately, keeping flexibility to apply to School_B if I meet them soon.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_C—thanks for reaching out. I’m glad to hear School_C is one of your top choices.

At School_C, our program emphasizes strong academics with structured support: clear course pathways, frequent check-ins, and targeted help (office hours/tutoring and advisor support) so students can stretch into rigorous classes without getting lost. We also put a lot of energy into clubs and student-led activities—students who take initiative tend to thrive here.

This year, we’re prioritizing applicants who show:
1) Consistent academic effort and growth (not just perfect scores—upward trajectory matters),
2) Reliability and follow-through (attendance, meeting commitments),
3) Positive contribution to the community (collaboration, leadership, helping peers), and
4) Genuine fit—students who can explain what they want to pursue here (academic interests, clubs, projects).

If you share 1–2 areas you’re most excited to explore (subjects or clubs) and what kind of support helps you do your best, I can be more specific about how you’d plug into School_C. And if you feel ready, we’d be happy to see an application from you.
conversation.thought: Student_C is #2 on our true priority list (behind Student_B). With quota 1 and no prior matches, we should strongly encourage Student_C to apply while keeping flexibility in case Student_B applies later. Since Student_C is currently in TALK mode, respond with program highlights and clearly signal strong interest and what we prioritize, aiming to convert to an application soon.

conversation.message: Hello School_D. I’m Student_D. I’m exploring options early and wanted to learn a bit more about your program and what you value most in applicants this year. I may consider applying later depending on how other options develop—could you share what would make a student a strong fit for School_D?
conversation.thought: School_D is last on my true preference list, so I should not commit early. I have decent priority at School_A (#2) and School_C (#3), and some chance at School_B (#4). Since this is round 1 and I haven’t contacted my top choices yet, I should keep School_D as a fallback and gather info rather than apply now.

conversation.message:
Hello Student_D—thanks for reaching out. At School_D, we value students who are intellectually curious, consistent in their effort, and eager to contribute to a supportive community. A strong fit is someone who:

1) Engages deeply with learning (asks questions, follows through, and enjoys challenge)
2) Shows steady responsibility (strong habits, reliability in group work, and good attendance/discipline)
3) Contributes to community (clubs, service, leadership or quiet but consistent teamwork)

Program-wise, we emphasize rigorous core academics with structured support: frequent teacher feedback, small-group help sessions, and clear pathways for advanced coursework. We also care a lot about student well-being and mentorship—students should feel known and supported, not anonymous.

If you’re still exploring, I’d love to learn what you’re looking for in a high school (academics, clubs, sports, support, commute, culture). What matters most to you, and what kinds of activities or subjects do you want to pursue? [TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_D is our top priority (#1). They currently rank us last, so they may not apply unless we actively differentiate and build interest. Since they only sent [TALK], we should respond with [TALK], highlight distinctive strengths, and invite/encourage an application while signaling strong mutual fit and priority consideration to influence their later decision.

conversation.message: Hello School_B. I’m Student_B, and School_B is one of my top choices. I’m very interested in joining your school and would like to formally apply this round. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_B is my 2nd choice (high). I have strong priority at School_B (2nd after Student_E), so applying now gives a good chance unless Student_E targets it. However, my top choice is School_A, where I have low priority (4th), making it risky to wait. Securing School_B early is a strong strategic move to ensure a high-ranked match.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for applying to School_B. You are a very strong fit for our school, and we would be excited to have you join our community. We are happy to offer you a place—welcome to School_B.
conversation.thought: Student_B is #2 on School_B's true priority list (very high). With quota 1 and no existing match, accepting now secures an excellent outcome. Although Student_E is #1, Student_E ranks School_B last and is unlikely to apply; Student_B may have School_A as first choice and could be accepted there if we delay. Therefore accept immediately and reinforce commitment.

conversation.message: Hello School_E—I'm Student_A. I’m very interested in learning more about your program and student life. Could you share what you value most in admitted students and what opportunities (clubs/academics/support) you’re especially proud of? I’d like to stay in touch as I make my decisions this round.
conversation.thought: School_E is 4th on my true list (B, C, A, E, D). In a student-proposing setting, applying early to a lower choice can lock me in and prevent pursuing B/C/A, where I might still have a chance later. Also, School_E ranks me #1 in its priority list, so if I need a safe option later, I can likely secure it then. Therefore I should not apply now; I should keep School_E warm with light talk and signal interest as a backup while aiming first for higher-ranked schools.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out. We’d be excited to stay in touch.

What we value most in admitted students:
- Curiosity and strong learning habits (students who ask good questions and follow through)
- Positive contribution to the community (collaboration, kindness, leadership in big or small ways)
- Resilience and growth mindset (willingness to improve, seek feedback, and persist)

Opportunities we’re especially proud of:
- Academics: rigorous core courses with enrichment options and structured academic coaching for students who want to accelerate or need targeted support
- Clubs & student life: student-led clubs across STEM, arts, service, and debate/speaking; it’s easy to start a new club with a faculty sponsor
- Support: advisory system, tutoring/office hours, and dedicated counseling for academic planning and wellbeing

To help me guide you better: what areas are you most excited about (STEM, humanities, arts, athletics, service), and what kind of support or challenge helps you thrive? If School_E is rising on your list, I’d encourage you to apply when you’re ready this round so we can seriously consider you.
conversation.thought: Student_A is my top priority (#1) and currently unmatched. They are only talking, not applying, so I should engage, highlight fit, and encourage an application soon while keeping flexibility since quota is 1 and other high-priority students (C, B) exist. No prior history; best move is to actively recruit and ask for an APPLY when ready.

conversation.message: Hello School_A. I’m Student_E. School_A is one of my top choices, especially because I’m looking for a strong academic environment and supportive guidance. Could you share what you value most in students and what your program emphasizes day-to-day? I’d love to learn a bit more before I decide where to formally apply this round.
conversation.thought: School_A is my 3rd choice (after School_C and School_D). I have top priority at School_A, so if I apply I’m very likely to be accepted and lock in a solid fallback. However, I may be able to secure School_C (my #1) later since School_C prioritizes me 4th and others (B, C, D) may outrank me there; School_D prioritizes me 4th as well. Given the one-shot-per-round constraint and no prior interactions, it’s worth signaling interest to School_A without committing yet, to preserve flexibility for higher choices in later rounds while keeping School_A warm.

conversation.message:
Hello Student_E—thank you for reaching out. We value students who are academically curious, consistent in their effort, and proactive about seeking feedback. Day-to-day, School_A emphasizes strong core instruction (especially in math, science, and writing), frequent formative check-ins so you always know where you stand, and structured support: office hours, peer study groups, and advisor meetings that focus on both performance and well-being.

We also look for students who contribute positively to the classroom community—respectful discussion, collaboration, and integrity matter a lot here.

If you’re aiming for a rigorous academic environment with steady guidance, School_A is a great fit. If you have particular interests (e.g., STEM competitions, humanities research, or leadership), tell me what you’re hoping to pursue and I can explain the most relevant tracks and supports. And if School_A is near the top of your list, I encourage you to consider submitting an application when you’re ready so we can seriously move forward.
conversation.thought: Student_E is School_A’s top priority. They are currently in TALK mode, so I should respond with TALK, strongly pitch our strengths, and encourage them to apply soon to secure the single seat. No prior commitments; quota is open. Given competition (other schools also rank E highly), I should actively appeal and invite an APPLY next round.

conversation.message: Hello School_C—I'm Student_E. School_C is my top choice because I’m looking for a rigorous academic environment with strong peer culture and clear teacher support. I’m especially interested in how you challenge students day-to-day and how you support them when courses get demanding. I would be excited to commit to School_C and contribute positively to the community. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_C is my #1 choice, so I should apply now. I’m mid-priority at School_C (behind B, C, D), but early application is important since capacity is 1 and others (especially Student_B and Student_C) may also target it. Best move is to apply with a strong, sincere pitch emphasizing fit and commitment.

conversation.message:
Student_E—thank you for applying, and I’m glad to hear School_C is your top choice.

On day-to-day rigor: we push with frequent problem sets/reading checks, discussion-based classes, and cumulative assessments that reward steady habits (not last-minute cramming). Many courses include extension options (challenge problems, deeper projects) so students can stretch.

On support when it gets demanding: teachers hold regular office hours, we run peer tutoring/study groups, and each student has an advisor who does check-ins—especially around major assessment periods. If you ever start slipping, we intervene early with a concrete plan (time management, targeted practice, and teacher follow-ups).

We’d be excited to have you contribute to our community. Welcome to School_C. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is on our true priority list (4th of 5). With quota 1 and higher-priority students (B, C, D) still potentially available, but uncertain whether they will apply and whether we can secure them, accepting Student_E now guarantees a match with an acceptable candidate who ranks us #1. Risk of rejecting is ending unmatched or getting a lower outcome if top candidates commit elsewhere. Therefore accept and lock in the seat.

conversation.message: Hello School_A—I'm Student_A. After reviewing my options this round, I’m excited to formally apply because your academics and overall environment are a strong fit for what I’m looking for. I’d be grateful for the opportunity to join School_A, and if admitted I’m prepared to commit and contribute actively to the school community.
conversation.thought: School_A is my 3rd choice (behind School_B and School_C). Given School_B is already matched, my best remaining outcome is School_C, but I am last in School_C’s priority so acceptance there is unlikely. School_A ranks me 3rd and may accept me if higher-priority students (E or D) go elsewhere. Since applying now could secure a decent match and reduce risk of ending up at low choices, I should apply to School_A with a strong but sincere commitment.

conversation.message: Hello Student_A—thank you for your application and for the thoughtful note. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We value students who will engage deeply in academics and contribute positively to the community, and your message strongly aligns with that. If you join us, we’ll make sure you have both the rigor and the support to thrive here. Welcome—please confirm your commitment and let us know what areas you’re most excited to pursue so we can help you get started on the right track. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_A is 3rd on School_A’s true priority list (E, D, A, B, C). With quota 1 and no current match, accepting A now secures a relatively high-priority student. Risk of holding out: Student_E ranks School_A 3rd and may apply elsewhere; Student_D ranks School_A 3rd as well; neither has applied yet. Given uncertainty and that A is a solid priority candidate, accept to lock in a good outcome rather than gamble for E or D.

conversation.message: Hello School_E—I'm Student_D. I’m still prioritizing a few options, but I’m genuinely interested in learning more about School_E. Could you share what you value most in applicants this year (academics, activities, fit), and what makes students successful once admitted? Also, do you have any particular programs or strengths you’d recommend I highlight if I decide to apply?
conversation.thought: School_E is 4th on my true list (B, C, A, E, D). Since it’s mid-low for me and early (round 2) with several schools still unmatched, I should not commit yet. Also, School_E’s priority list ranks me last, so an immediate APPLY is unlikely to succeed unless stronger candidates go elsewhere. Best move is to TALK: express interest while gathering info and keeping options open for higher-ranked schools.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_D—thanks for reaching out. Here’s what we value most in applicants this year, and what tends to make students thrive at School_E.

What we value in applicants:
- Academic readiness + habits: consistent effort, strong fundamentals, and evidence you can manage a rigorous workload (not just top scores).
- Curiosity and initiative: pursuing interests beyond the classroom—projects, reading, competitions, community work, or self-driven learning.
- Community contribution (“fit”): collaboration, kindness, and taking responsibility in groups (clubs, teams, class leadership, peer support).
- Growth mindset: students who seek feedback, reflect, and show improvement over time.

What makes students successful once admitted:
- Using support early (office hours, advising, tutoring/coaching) rather than waiting until things pile up.
- Balancing challenge with consistency—steady weekly routines beat last-minute pushes.
- Getting involved in at least one community activity to build connections and leadership.

Programs/strengths to highlight if you apply (choose what’s authentic):
- Any sustained academic interest (STEM/humanities/arts) where you can show depth over time.
- Leadership or impact in a club/team/service activity (even informal leadership counts if you can explain your role).
- A “builder” mindset: starting something, improving a process, mentoring others, or sticking with a long-term goal.

To tailor guidance: what are your top 2 academic interests, and what activities have you been most committed to this year? Also, where does School_E currently sit among your options (top choice / top 2-3 / still exploring)?
conversation.thought: Student_D is on our true priority list but ranked lowest (5th). With quota 1 and higher-priority students (A, C, B, E) still unmatched, we should not commit yet. Student_D is only talking, so we respond with [TALK], provide info, and probe likelihood of applying/fit while keeping the door open without signaling guaranteed acceptance.

conversation.message: Hello School_D, I’m Student_C. I’m very interested in School_D because I’m looking for a rigorous environment with strong student support, and I think I’d be a good fit for your community. I’d like to formally apply and be considered for your open seat. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_D is my 3rd choice (after School_B and School_C). With School_B already matched, I should prioritize securing a strong option while still leaving room to pursue School_C later. I have decent priority at School_D (3rd in their list), so an early application could succeed before higher-priority students crowd it out. Therefore, apply now with a clear expression of fit and commitment.

conversation.message:
Hello Student_C—thank you for your application and for clearly explaining what you’re looking for. Your interest in rigorous academics paired with strong support aligns closely with what we emphasize at School_D, and we believe you would be a strong fit for our community.

We’re happy to move forward with you for our open seat. Welcome to School_D—if you’d like, share the subjects or activities you’re most excited to pursue so we can point you toward the best courses and clubs to start with.
conversation.thought: Student_C is on our true priority list (3rd). With quota 1 and no current match, accepting now secures a desirable candidate. While Student_D is our top choice, they have not applied and may prefer other schools; holding out risks ending unmatched or with a lower-priority student. Accepting Student_C aligns with our priorities and fills the seat with a strong fit.

conversation.message: Hello School_E—thank you for the info earlier. At this point I’m ready to move forward: I’m applying to School_E. I’m confident I’d contribute positively to the community and take full advantage of your programs, and I’m prepared to commit if accepted. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched in round 3, so I likely failed to secure my higher choices (B, C, A). School_E is still on my true list (4th), and being unmatched is worse than matching with E. I should apply now to lock in the last available seat. School_E’s priority ranks me last, but if they are still unmatched, their higher-priority students likely matched elsewhere, so an application now has a good chance.

conversation.message: Student_D—thank you for applying and for the thoughtful conversation earlier. We appreciate your readiness to contribute to our community and fully engage with our programs. We’re happy to offer you a place at School_E. If you’re ready to commit as you mentioned, please confirm your intent and we’ll share next steps and onboarding details right away. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D is on School_E’s true priority list but ranked last (A, C, B, E, D). Remaining unmatched students list shows only Student_D, and School_E has full quota available. With no other candidates available this round and risk of ending unmatched, it is better to accept Student_D rather than leave the seat empty, since they are included on the acceptable list and are applying with commitment.
